page.title: 09FARMING
page.content: As late as the nineteenth century this was very much a no-mans-land liable to be covered with sea water. Since, however, the land has been opened up and drained by means of rhines (pronounced REENS - local word for drainage ditches) farmers carry on mixed farming. There are approx.10 working farms, the majority of the land is owned by the Chemical works so most of the farmers are employed. South of the railway line farming is restricted to sheep, beef and arable, whilst on the north of the railway line there are some dairy herds and cereal crops. Farms consist of small fields bounded by hedgerows and rhines.
